Here is a simple way from affective neuroscience to increase dopamine (arousal) and opioid (pleasure) in the brain, and to increase productivity and self-motivation.

Hypothesis and proof below.

HYPOTHESIS: Dopamine release will stimulate endogenous opioid systems when the latter are in a non-suppressed state.
EXPLANATION AND ‘PROOF’: Activity that involves continuous positive act/outcome discrepancy or novelty (productive or meaningful behavior) while the covert musculature is inactive (a resting state) will result in heightened feeling of pleasure and arousal, or ‘eudaemonia’, ‘flow’, or ‘peak’ experience. This derives from the observation that neuro-muscular tension (or stress) inhibits endogenous opioid (pleasure) release, while relaxation accentuates it, the latter permitting opioid systems to be further stimulated by increased dopamine release (arousal) elicited by meaningful behavior.
The reason this explanation does not appear evident from general observation is that its counterpart as ‘flow’ or ‘peak’ experience is described through literary metaphor and not scientific language and obscures the independent and dependent measures that accurately describe it. The virtue of this explanation is that it is easily testable by anyone. Just get into a relaxed state (mindfulness protocols are the best way to do this) and then exclusively pursue or anticipate pursuing productive activity for periods of a half hour or so, and voila, you will have a flow or eudaemonic experience. It is that simple.

I offer a more detailed explanation in pp. 47-52, and pp 82-86 of my open source book on the neuroscience of resting states, ‘The Book of Rest’, linked below.
https://www.scribd.com/doc/284056765/The-Book-of-Rest-The-Odd-Psychology-of-Doing-Nothing

This above book is based on the research of the distinguished neuroscientist Kent Berridge of the University of Michigan, a preeminent researcher and authority on dopamine, addiction, and motivation, who was kind to vet the work for accuracy and endorse the finished manuscript. Berridge’s Site and his article from ‘Scientific American’ magazine on the neuroscience of happiness.
https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/berridge-lab/
https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/berridge-lab/wp-content/uploads/sites/743/2019/10/Kringelbach-Berridge-2012-Joyful-mind-Sci-Am.pdf

While this technology has some valid uses there is a great danger it will be used simplistically and counter-productively.Suppose I'm depressed because I lost my wife, my job, and my dog. I go to the bar and have a few drinks and I'm no longer depressed. Or the doctor hacks my brain and makes me no longer depressed. But SHOULDN'T I be depressed? We don't want a society of people whose happiness is unrelated to what's going on with their family, friends, job, the world around us. To be a person is to have a history and some sort of reasonable attitude to that history. Gerry-rigging our emotions and behavior with crude interventions will destroy the coherence of the personality. Nor do I think you could hack someone's brain to believe that Lincoln is still president because they would wonder why Biden is Vice President and why Lincoln is still alive at age 200. Question number 1: It's actually not the soda that makes your pee yellow. The colour of your pee is determined by Urobilin, or urochrome. When you drink water, the ratio's of the 'waste' (the chemicals your body didn't do anything with/ what is left after processing) change, therefore the colour changes. Less water equals a higher ratio of Urobilin equals darker yellow colourd pee.

Howdy AsapSCIENCE,
As a Cochlear Implant user, I want to say that you guys are very close, but not entirely correct about CI's.
The CI does not directly input into the brain. It still uses what is called your Cochlea. In many deaf individuals, the the hair cells in your cochlea, which turn the vibrations of your ear drum into electronic signals, are damaged. The brain doesn't really work like that. You only use specific neurons for specific tasks. If you were to activate all your neurons at once, you'd basically get an epileptic seizure. Like in a seizure, all your muscles would start moving (because all their respective neurons are firing). You wouldn't even be able to think anymore, because there's just a rush of activity all around your brain. Think of it like white noise on a tv. There's a lot of pixels active, but no patterns, no information.

Great video as always. But you did make one mistake in it. The cochlear implant does not send electrical impulses to the brain. It doesn't do anything with the brain. It sends the impulses to the cochlea. It stimulates the hair nerves in the cochlea (which are normally stimulated by motion similar to a needle on a record player). From there it travels to the hearing nerve then to the brain just like normal hearing does. (I've had my CI since 2009).
